speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you first started showing signs of feeding intolerance and bilious vomiting? Was it shortly after birth or did it develop over time?

speaker: Patient
text: It started right after birth, I remember being hungry and trying to feed, but I just couldn't keep anything down. The first time I vomited, it was a little bit of milk, but the next time it was bile, and that's when I knew something was wrong.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your mother's pregnancy, did she have any complications or any pre-existing medical conditions that might be relevant to your condition?

speaker: Patient
text: My mom missed a few prenatal checkups, and she did have some concerns about the baby's growth, but the doctor just told her everything was fine. I don't know if that's relevant, but she did seem a bit worried about it at the time.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the frequency and duration of these episodes of vomiting? Are they constant, or do they come and go at certain times of the day? And would you say that your abdomen is ever tender to the touch, or does it feel normal?

speaker: Patient
text: The vomiting episodes started within the first hour after birth, and they've been happening pretty much nonstop since then. I don't really know what the pattern is, it just keeps happening. My tummy does feel a bit uncomfortable after feeding, but it's not really tender, more like... uneasy.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your mother's prenatal care? Did she have any ultrasounds or other tests that might have shown something abnormal? Also, I'd like to perform a physical examination to assess your abdomen and look for any signs of distension or other abnormalities.

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think she had any ultrasounds or anything like that. I just remember her saying that the doctor told her everything was fine and that the baby was growing just fine, but she did seem a bit worried about it. She was just really scared to have a normal delivery because of all the things she was reading online.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your mother's overall health and well-being during the pregnancy? Did she have any pre-existing medical conditions or take any medications that might be relevant to your condition? And during the physical examination, I'd like to check for any signs of distension or abnormalities in your abdomen. Can you please lift your shirt and let me examine your abdomen?

speaker: Patient
text: My mom's been pretty healthy, just a bit anxious about the pregnancy, I guess. She's been taking prenatal vitamins and all that, but I don't think she's had any pre-existing conditions. As for the exam, yeah, I can lift my shirt. *lifts shirt* Go ahead and take a look.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to request test: Complete Blood Count (CBC) to check for any signs of infection or inflammation. Also, can you tell me more about the color and consistency of the bile you've been vomiting? Is it a thick, yellowish liquid or more of a thin, greenish liquid?

speaker: Patient
text: The bile I've been vomiting is a pretty yellowish color, almost like honey, and it's been coming out pretty thick, almost like a syrup. It's hard to describe, but it's definitely not just milk.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the frequency of your vomiting episodes, do they seem to be getting worse or staying the same over time? And regarding the test results, I'll get those back to me as soon as possible. In the meantime, I'd like to request test: Urinalysis to check for any signs of dehydration or electrolyte imbalances. Also, during the physical examination, I noticed that your abdomen seems slightly tender to the touch in the upper right quadrant, could you confirm that for me?

speaker: Patient
text: The vomiting episodes do seem to be getting worse, it feels like they're just getting more frequent and intense. I don't know if it's because I'm getting hungrier or if it's because of something else, but it just feels like it's getting harder to keep anything down. Regarding the test results, I don't know what to expect, but I hope it's not something serious. And yeah, my tummy does feel a bit tender, especially when I'm trying to eat or after feeding, it's like there's something bothering it. Can you tell me more about what's going on with the test results? Are they going to show something specific that might help figure out what's going on with me?

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to request test: Blood Chemistry Panel to check for any signs of liver or pancreatic dysfunction. Can you tell me more about the sensation in your abdomen, is it more of a cramping or a dull ache? Also, I'd like to request test: Abdominal Ultrasound to get a better look at your abdominal organs.

speaker: Patient
text: I'd say it's more of a dull ache, like my tummy's just feeling a bit off. It's hard to explain, but it's like there's something in there that's not quite right. And yeah, the ultrasound sounds good, I'd be happy to have that done. I'm just worried about what it might show, you know?

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to request test: Liver Function Tests (LFTs) to check for any signs of liver dysfunction. Can you tell me more about the sensation in your abdomen, is it more of a cramping or a dull ache? Also, I'd like to check for any signs of jaundice, such as yellowing of the skin or eyes.

speaker: Patient
text: It's just a dull ache, like my tummy's just feeling a bit off. It's hard to explain, but it's like there's something in there that's not quite right. Doctor: Can you tell me more about the sensation in your abdomen? Is it more of a cramping or a dull ache? Patient: Like I said, it's a dull ache. It's not really cramping, but more of a feeling of unease or discomfort.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of the bile you've been vomiting? Is it a burning sensation, or more of a thick, sticky feeling in your mouth and throat? And have you noticed any other symptoms, such as diarrhea or abdominal pain, besides the vomiting and the dull ache in your abdomen?

speaker: Patient
text: It's a bit sticky, like honey, and it feels like it's sticking to the roof of my mouth. As for other symptoms, besides the vomiting and the dull ache, I have been having some trouble breathing after feeding, like my chest feels a bit tight.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the trouble you're having breathing after feeding? Is it a persistent feeling of tightness in your chest, or does it come and go? Also, I'd like to request test: Electrolyte Panel to check for any signs of electrolyte imbalances. And can you point to the exact spot on your abdomen where it feels tender to the touch?

speaker: Patient
text: It's hard to explain, but it feels like my chest is getting a bit tight after feeding, and it's hard to catch my breath. Sometimes it feels like there's a weight on my chest, and I get a bit lightheaded.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of the tightness in your chest? Is it a persistent feeling, or does it come and go with feeding? And regarding the electrolyte panel, do you have any pre-existing conditions that might affect your kidney function or the way your body processes electrolytes? Also, I'd like to request test: Chest X-Ray to see if there's any evidence of fluid buildup or other abnormalities in your lungs.

speaker: Patient
text: The tightness in my chest feels like it's coming and going, it's not always there but when it is, it feels like I'm having trouble breathing and my chest feels really tight. I've also noticed that when I vomit, the tightness in my chest seems to get worse, it's like the vomiting is making it harder to breathe.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your symptoms when you're not actively vomiting? Do you experience any discomfort or pain when your abdomen is at rest? Also, I'd like to request test: Electrolyte Panel to check for any signs of electrolyte imbalances. And, I'd like to review the ultrasound results, can you please send them over to me?

speaker: Patient
text: When I'm not vomiting, I don't really feel anything different, it's just like my tummy's always a bit off, but I guess that's just the constant feeling of being sick, I don't know. I do get a bit lightheaded sometimes, but it's not really a pain, more like a feeling of being a bit dizzy.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the lightheadedness you experience? Is it a feeling of being on the verge of passing out, or more of a general feeling of dizziness? Also, I'd like to request test: Potassium Level to check for any signs of electrolyte imbalances.

speaker: Patient
text: It's just a feeling of being a bit dizzy, like I'm not quite standing up straight or anything. I get a bit lightheaded when I stand up too quickly or when I'm feeling really sick.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to request test: Potassium Level to check for any signs of electrolyte imbalances. Also, can you tell me more about your symptoms when you're not actively vomiting? Do you experience any discomfort or pain when your abdomen is at rest? Additionally, I'd like to request test: Liver Function Tests (LFTs) to check for any signs of liver dysfunction. Can you point to the exact spot on your abdomen where it feels tender to the touch again?

speaker: Doctor

speaker: Patient
